phase1_analysis:
STEP 1 â€” Individual example analyses

Important common facts for all examples: each input is 3Ã—3 and each output is 9Ã—9. Colors seen across the examples are only from the set [0,2,4,6,7] where 0 is background (black) and 2,4,6,7 are the colored objects. In every example the transformation is a geometric scaling: each input cell is expanded into a 3Ã—3 block of the same color in the output.

Example 1 (first input â†’ first output)
- Input objects: color 6 pixels (magenta) arranged in a small hooked/C-like shape on a black (color 0) 3Ã—3 canvas.
- Output objects: color 6 forms the same hooked/C-like shape but scaled up and rendered on a 9Ã—9 black background.
- What changed: each color 6 pixel in the 3Ã—3 input became a 3Ã—3 contiguous block of color 6 in the 9Ã—9 output. No new colors were introduced and no color pixels changed identity.
- What stayed the same: the relative shape/arrangement of the colored pixels is preserved, and the background remains color 0. The output dimension increased from 3Ã—3 â†’ 9Ã—9.
- Why it changed this way: the transformation maps every input cell to a 3Ã—3 block in the output, so the small shape is reproduced at 3Ã— scale without changing colors.

Example 2 (second input â†’ second output)
- Input objects: color 4 pixels (yellow) in a sparse arrangement on a black 3Ã—3 canvas (a small pattern of isolated yellow cells).
- Output objects: color 4 appears in the 9Ã—9 output as larger 3Ã—3 yellow blocks at positions corresponding to the original yellow cells.
- What changed: each original color 4 pixel was expanded to a 3Ã—3 block of color 4. No pixels changed color or were merged with other colors.
- What stayed the same: the pattern of which input cells were colored vs background is preserved, only scaled. The background remains color 0.
- Why: same rule â€” each 3Ã—3 input cell becomes a 3Ã—3 block in the output, preserving the pattern.

Example 3 (third input â†’ third output)
- Input objects: color 2 pixels (red) arranged as short vertical and horizontal bars on the 3Ã—3 input.
- Output objects: color 2 appears as corresponding larger bars in the 9Ã—9 output (each input pixel replaced by a 3Ã—3 red block).
- What changed/stayed same & why: identical reasoning â€” geometric upscaling by factor 3 with preservation of color and relative layout.

Example 4 (fourth input â†’ fourth output)
- Input objects: color 2 pixels (red) arranged as horizontal bars in the 3Ã—3 cell.
- Output objects: those bars are reproduced at 3Ã— scale (3Ã—3 blocks) in the 9Ã—9 output.
- Change/stay/why: same scaling rule as above.

Example 5 (fifth input â†’ fifth output)
- Input objects: color 7 pixels (light blue) arranged in a small shape on the 3Ã—3 canvas.
- Output objects: color 7 forms the same shape scaled into 3Ã—3 blocks on the 9Ã—9 background.
- Change/stay/why: again, each input cell â†’ 3Ã—3 region of the same color.

STEP 2 â€” Compare across examples

INPUTS â€” common vs different
- Same in all inputs: all are 3Ã—3 grids, use only colors {0 plus one nonzero color per example}, and contain small shapes made of one nonzero color on a black (color 0) background.
- Different between inputs: the nonzero color and the particular pixel pattern vary (example-to-example the colored pixels occupy different cells and the active color changes between 2,4,6,7).
- Why consistent: the rule applies equally regardless of which of the allowed nonzero colors is present or where its pixels lie.

OUTPUTS â€” common vs different
- Same in all outputs: all are 9Ã—9, background is still color 0, and every colored input pixel becomes a filled 3Ã—3 block of the same color in the corresponding scaled position.
- Different: which color appears and where depends on the input pattern.
- Why consistent: a uniform scaling transform is applied to every example.

STEP 3 â€” Transformation by color

- Color 0 (background): stays background. In the 9Ã—9 output, input background cells become 3Ã—3 background blocks. The background is preserved and simply fills more cells because the grid is scaled.
- Color 2 (red): each color 2 pixel in the 3Ã—3 input is replaced by a 3Ã—3 contiguous block of color 2 in the output at the scaled coordinates.
- Color 4 (yellow): same as color 2 â€” expanded to 3Ã—3 blocks, preserving pattern.
- Color 6 (magenta): same behavior â€” each pixel becomes a 3Ã—3 magenta block.
- Color 7 (light blue): same behavior â€” scaled to 3Ã—3 blocks.

Which colors are affected: all nonzero colors {2,4,6,7} are scaled in identical fashion. Which colors stay the same: color identities remain unchanged (no recoloring). No color interactions occur â€” colors do not mix or replace each other; they are simply enlarged in place.

Causal reasoning: The purpose is to produce a larger canvas that preserves the original pattern while scaling it uniformly so each original cell maps to a 3Ã—3 tile. This preserves topology and relative positions while enlarging the pattern for easier visual recognition or tiling.

STEP 4 â€” Grid size pattern

- Relationship: outputs are 3Ã— larger in each dimension (3 â†’ 9). Equivalently, each dimension is multiplied by 3.
- Are outputs same size? No, outputs are larger.
- Why necessary: the rule maps each single input cell to a 3Ã—3 block in the output; thus the full 3Ã—3 input becomes 9Ã—9.
- Purpose: to create space for the enlarged representation of each input cell and preserve the input pattern at a higher resolution.

STEP 5 â€” General transformation pattern (summary, with WHY)

The transformation uniformly scales the 3Ã—3 input by a factor of 3 in each direction, producing a 9Ã—9 output: every input cell (whether color 0,2,4,6 or 7) is replaced by a 3Ã—3 block of the same color at coordinates (3r .. 3r+2, 3c .. 3c+2). This preserves the original pattern shape and color identity while enlarging it. The rule applies to any of the nonzero colors (2, 4, 6, 7) and leaves color 0 as background, so the output is a faithful 3Ã—-scaled version of the input for visualization or tiling purposes.
pattern_summary:
OBJECT INVENTORY (verify first):

- Training 1 objects:
  - multi-cell irregular object (color 7, 7-cell shape, bounding box rows 1-3, cols 1-3; filled cells at (1,2),(1,3),(2,1),(2,2),(2,3),(3,2),(3,3))

- Training 2 objects:
  - single-cell object (color 4, 1×1, row 1, col 1)
  - single-cell object (color 4, 1×1, row 1, col 3)
  - single-cell object (color 4, 1×1, row 3, col 2)

- Training 3 objects:
  - single-cell object (color 2, 1×1, row 2, col 3)
  - single-cell object (color 2, 1×1, row 3, col 1)
  - single-cell object (color 2, 1×1, row 3, col 3)

- Training 4 objects:
  - multi-cell irregular object (color 6, 5-cell shape, bounding box rows 1-3, cols 1-3; filled cells at (1,1),(1,2),(2,1),(3,2),(3,3))

- Training 5 objects:
  - 1×3 rectangle (color 2, 1×3 block, rows 1-1, cols 1-3)
  - 1×2 rectangle (color 2, 1×2 block, rows 3-3, cols 2-3)

UNIVERSAL PATTERN SUMMARY:
- The input 3×3 grid is scaled up to a 9×9 output by mapping each input cell to a 3×3 tile in the output. First an empty 9×9 background is created, then every input cell is expanded into a corresponding 3×3 block of the same color, and finally any 3×3 block that corresponds to a nonzero input cell is replaced by a copy of the original 3×3 input pattern recolored so foreground pixels use the block's color and zeros remain background.

STEP-BY-STEP PATTERN:

Step 1: FILL - Create/initialize the output as an empty background grid (color 0, 9×9, rows 1-9, cols 1-9).

Step 2: EXPAND - For each input cell (color X, 1×1, row r, col c) expand it into a corresponding 3×3 output block (color X, 3×3, rows 3r..3r+2, cols 3c..3c+2) and fill that block with X (if X=0 the block is all background). (Apply this for every input cell; if no such cell exists, do nothing.)

Step 3: FILL - For each 3×3 output block that was created from a nonzero input cell (color X, 3×3, rows 3r..3r+2, cols 3c..3c+2) replace that entire 3×3 block with the original 3×3 input pattern as follows: for each position (i,j) in the original input (i=1..3, j=1..3) set the block cell at (row 3r + (i-1), col 3c + (j-1)) to X if the original input at (i,j) is nonzero, otherwise set it to 0. (If no nonzero blocks exist, do nothing.)

Notes/conditions:
- Steps refer to "each input cell" and "each nonzero block" so they are applied repeatedly for all cells/blocks in every example.
- Color identities are preserved: the recoloring in Step 3 uses the block's color X for all foreground pixels copied from the input pattern; background stays color 0.

steps.description: FILL: Initialize the output as an empty background grid (color 0, size 9×9, rows 1-9 cols 1-9). Verification of test input before executing step: the 3×3 input contains two distinct color-7 objects:

EXPAND: Expand each input cell into a corresponding 3×3 block in the 9×9 output. Specifically, every nonzero input cell (color 7) is expanded to a 3×3 block of color 7 at the output block positions corresponding to its input (rows 1-3,4-6,7-9 and cols 1-3,4-6,7-9); zero input cells produce all-background 3×3 blocks.

FILL: For each 3×3 output block created from a nonzero input cell (color 7) replace that block with the original 3×3 input pattern recolored to color 7. Affected blocks (by input cell): (1,1)->rows1-3 cols1-3, (1,3)->rows1-3 cols7-9, (2,1)->rows4-6 cols1-3, (2,3)->rows4-6 cols7-9, (3,1)->rows7-9 cols1-3, (3,2)->rows7-9 cols4-6. Blocks corresponding to zero input cells remain all background.
